repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
The RelWithDebInfo build type was using redundant optimization flags.
Before this PR, RelWithDebInfo builds generated by redundant flags like this:

```
Compilation: /usr/bin/cc -O2 -g -Og -g
```

this PR fix this:

```
Compilation: /usr/bin/cc -O2 -g
```

# Motivation

The `CMAKE_C_FLAGS_RELWITHDEBINFO` variable was being modified in a way that caused duplicate `-Og` and `-g` flags to be added. The resulting flags were `-O2 -g -Og -g`.

*   `-Og` (Optimize for debugging) and `-O2` (Optimize for performance) are different optimization levels. We can't use both at once.
*   The duplicate `-g` flag is redundant and no effect.

multiple -O flags has no effect for code, just redundant.

> If you use multiple -O options, with or without level numbers, the last such option is the one that is effective.

https://gcc.gnu.org/onlinedocs/gcc/Optimize-Options.html

### Before this PR

```
:verbose version
NVIM v0.11.0-dev-1443+ge00cd1ab40
Build type: RelWithDebInfo
LuaJIT 2.1.1734355927
Compilation: /usr/bin/cc -O2 -g -Og -g -flto -fno-fat-lto-ob
jects -Wall -Wextra -pedantic -Wno-unused-parameter -Wstrict
-prototypes -std=gnu99 -Wshadow -Wconversion -Wvla -Wdouble-
promotion -Wmissing-noreturn -Wmissing-format-attribute -Wmi
ssing-prototypes -fsigned-char -fstack-protector-strong -Wno
-conversion -fno-common -Wno-unused-result -Wimplicit-fallth
rough -fdiagnostics-color=always  -DUNIT_TESTING -D_GNU_SOUR
CE -DINCLUDE_GENERATED_DECLARATIONS -DUTF8PROC_STATIC -I/hom
e/sys9kdr/workspace/neovim/.deps/usr/include/luajit-2.1 -I/h
ome/sys9kdr/workspace/neovim/.deps/usr/include -I/home/sys9k
dr/workspace/neovim/build/src/nvim/auto -I/home/sys9kdr/work
space/neovim/build/include -I/home/sys9kdr/workspace/neovim/
build/cmake.config -I/home/sys9kdr/workspace/neovim/src -I/u
sr/include

   system vimrc file: "$VIM/sysinit.vim"
  fall-back for $VIM: "/usr/local/share/nvim"
```

### After this PR

```
:verbose version
NVIM v0.11.0-dev-e00cd1ab4-dirty
Build type: RelWithDebInfo
LuaJIT 2.1.1734355927
Compilation: /usr/bin/cc -O2 -g -flto -fno-fat-lto-objects -
Wall -Wextra -pedantic -Wno-unused-parameter -Wstrict-protot
ypes -std=gnu99 -Wshadow -Wconversion -Wvla -Wdouble-promoti
on -Wmissing-noreturn -Wmissing-format-attribute -Wmissing-p
rototypes -fsigned-char -fstack-protector-strong -Wno-conver
sion -fno-common -Wno-unused-result -Wimplicit-fallthrough -
fdiagnostics-color=always  -DUNIT_TESTING -D_GNU_SOURCE -DIN
CLUDE_GENERATED_DECLARATIONS -DUTF8PROC_STATIC -I/home/sys9k
dr/workspace/neovim-fork/.deps/usr/include/luajit-2.1 -I/hom
e/sys9kdr/workspace/neovim-fork/.deps/usr/include -I/home/sy
s9kdr/workspace/neovim-fork/build/src/nvim/auto -I/home/sys9
kdr/workspace/neovim-fork/build/include -I/home/sys9kdr/work
space/neovim-fork/build/cmake.config -I/home/sys9kdr/workspa
ce/neovim-fork/src -I/usr/include

   system vimrc file: "$VIM/sysinit.vim"
  fall-back for $VIM: "/usr/local/share/nvim"

Run :checkhealth for more info
```

comment_data.body:
We explicitly wanted to use `-Og` for RelWithDebInfo with compilers that support it. Calling the compiler with `-O2 -g -Og -g` is perfectly fine, as you stated, since the latter option takes precedence.

If any options should be removed, it should be the first set.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -149,11 +149,6 @@ set(NVIM_API_LEVEL 13)        # Bump this after any API/stdlib change.
 set(NVIM_API_LEVEL_COMPAT 0)  # Adjust this after a _breaking_ API change.
 set(NVIM_API_PRERELEASE true)
 
-# Build-type: RelWithDebInfo
-# /Og means something different in MSVC
-if(CMAKE_C_COMPILER_ID MATCHES "GNU" OR CMAKE_C_COMPILER_ID MATCHES "Clang")
-   set(CMAKE_C_FLAGS_RELWITHDEBINFO "${CMAKE_C_FLAGS_RELWITHDEBINFO} -Og -g")

comment_data.body:
We should remove `-O2 -g`?  But `-O2 -g` is a default for RelWithDebInfo and many projects choose `-O2` over `-Og`.

The RelWithDebInfo configuration is designed to strike a balance between performance and debugging. -Og skews heavily towards debugging at the cost of runtime performance, which contradicts the purpose of this configuration.

e.g. LLVM use `-O2` for RelWithDebInfo

> RelWithDebInfo
> 
> These builds are useful when debugging. They generate optimized binaries with debug information. CMakes default optimization level is -O2. This can be configured by setting the CMAKE_CXX_FLAGS_RELWITHDEBINFO variable on the CMake command line.

https://releases.llvm.org/11.0.1/docs/GettingStarted.html

RelWithDebInfo means release builds that contains debug info.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -149,11 +149,6 @@ set(NVIM_API_LEVEL 13)        # Bump this after any API/stdlib change.
 set(NVIM_API_LEVEL_COMPAT 0)  # Adjust this after a _breaking_ API change.
 set(NVIM_API_PRERELEASE true)
 
-# Build-type: RelWithDebInfo
-# /Og means something different in MSVC
-if(CMAKE_C_COMPILER_ID MATCHES "GNU" OR CMAKE_C_COMPILER_ID MATCHES "Clang")
-   set(CMAKE_C_FLAGS_RELWITHDEBINFO "${CMAKE_C_FLAGS_RELWITHDEBINFO} -Og -g")

comment_regular_data.body:
-O2 -g is significantly more effective than -Og -g, particularly for RelWithDebInfo builds.

The key issue is that -Og disables many critical optimizations, making the debug build behavior substantially different from production.

With -O2 -g, we get:

* Runtime characteristics much closer to release builds
* More accurate profiling results
* Better detection of optimization-related issues
* We can still check code with GDB

`-Og` is not for builds, it is for daily development at local.

https://gcc.gnu.org/onlinedocs/gcc/Optimize-Options.html says:

> Optimize debugging experience. -Og should be the optimization level of choice for the standard edit-compile-debug cycle, offering a reasonable level of optimization while maintaining fast compilation and a good debugging experience. It is a better choice than -O0 for producing debuggable code because some compiler passes that collect debug information are disabled at -O0.

I think we should choose `-O2 -g` at RelWithDebInfo and `-Og -g`(or `-Og -g3`) at Debug.
or no `-O` flags, just `-g` or `-g3` for debug builds.
I've fixed my commit message and force-pushed.

> * `-Og` (Optimize for debugging) and `-O2` (Optimize for performance) are different optimization levels. We can't use both at once.
> * The duplicate `-g` flag is redundant and no effect.
> 
> multiple -O flags has no effect for code, just redundant.

This is the kernel of the "Problem" description, please include it in the commit message
`-g3` would be a useful addition. I'm always annoyed when the debugger can't tell me what defines are, but I'm ok with this as is.

@justinmk @jamessan This is GDB output with `-O2 -g`(without `-Og -g`), is that enough? Not sure, what info  neovim-devs need.

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/a29a54b7-d022-48c2-a390-8b0311e3b3b0)

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/bc54bb8a-98d5-4e48-81a7-2923bd9e2ff7)

@justinmk This commit is okay?

```
    build: fix RelWithDebInfo optimization flags

    Problem:
    The RelWithDebInfo flags were redundant(-O2 -g -Og -g).
    And -Og is not ideal for RelWithDebInfo.

    Solution:
    Adjusted the flags to use the more appropriate -O2 -g.
```

@jamessan `-g3` is suitable for Debug builds, but it might be a bit excessive for RelWithDebInfo.

I'll update my commit again, `-O2 -g` is enough.
@sys9kdr thanks for this attention to detail.

title: build: Fix RelWithDebInfo optimization flags
